sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: But now people will call you valiant, deſertleſly I thinke yet for their ſatiſfaction, I wil haue you fight with me.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: O my good Lord, my deepe ingagements.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Tell not me of your ingagements, Captaine Beſſus; it is not to be put off with an excuſe: for my owne part, I am none of the multitude that beleeue your conuerſion from coward.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſeeke not quarrels, and this belongs not to me, I am not to maintaine it.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Who then pray?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Beſſus the coward wrong'd you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: And ſhall Beſſus the valiant, maintaine what Beſſus the coward did?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I prethee leaue theſe cheating trickes, I ſweare thou ſhalt fight with mee, or thou ſhalt be beate extreamely, and kickt.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Since you prouoke me thus farre my Lord, I will fight with you; and by my Sword it ſhall coſt me twenty pounds, but I will haue my legge a weeke ſooner purpoſely.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Your legge, why what ailes your legge? Ile doe a cure on you, ſtand vp.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: My Lord, this is not noble in you:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: What doſt thou with ſuch a phraſe in thy mouth?
I will kicke thee out of all good words before I leaue thee.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.l: My Lord, I take this as a puniſhment for the offence
I did when I was a coward.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: When thou wert? confeſſe thy ſelfe a coward ſtill, or by this light, Ile beate thee into ſpunge.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Why I am one:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Are you ſo Sir, and why doe you weare a ſword then? Come, vnbuckle, quicke.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Vnbuckle I ſay, and giue it mee, or as I liue, thy head will ake extreamely.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: It is a pretty hilt, and if your Lordſhip take an affection to it, with all my heart, I preſent it to you for a new-yeers gift.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I thanke you very heartily, ſweete Captaine farewell.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: One word more, I beſeech your Lordſhip to render me my knife againe.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Marry by all meanes Captaine, cheriſh your ſelfe with it, and eate hard good Captaine; we cannot tell whether we ſhall haue any more ſuch: A due deare Captaine.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: I will make better vſe of this, then of my ſword: A baſe ſpirit has this vantage of a braue one; it keepes alwayes at a ſtay, nothing brings it downe, not beating. I remember I promiſt the King in a great audience, that I would make my back-byters eate my ſword to a knife, how to get another ſword I know not, nor know any meanes left for me to maintaine my credit but impudence: Therefore will I outſweare him and all his followers, that this is all is left vneaten of my ſword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ile mone the King, hee is moſt ſtrangely alter'd; I gueſſe the cauſe I feare too right, Heauen has ſome ſecret end in't, and tis a ſecurge no queſtion iuſtly laid vpon him: Hee has followed mee through twenty roomes, and euer when I ſtay to await his command, he bluſhes like a girle, and lookes vpon me, as if modeſtie kept in his buſineſſe: ſo turnes away from me, but if I goe on, hee followes me againe. See, here he is, I doe not vſe this, yet I know not how, I cannot chuſe but weepe to ſee him: his very enemies I thinke, whoſe wounds haue bred his fame, if they ſhould ſee him now, would find teares in their eyes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I cannot vtter it, why ſhould I keepe
A breaſt to harbour thoughts? I dare not ſpeake:
Darkeneſſe is in my boſome, and there lies
A thouſand thoughts that cannot brooke the light;
How wilt thou vex me when this deede is done
Conſcience? that art afraid to let me name it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How doe you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why very well Mardonius; how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Better then you I feare.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I hope thou art; for to be plain • with thee,
Thou art in hell elſe: ſecret ſcorching flam • s
That farre tranſcend earthly materiall fiers,
Art crept into me, and there is no cure;
Is not that ſtrange Mardonius, theres no cure?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, either I miſtake, or there is ſomething hid
That you would vtter to me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: So there is, but yet I cannot doe it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Out with it Sir, i • it be dangerous I ſhall not ſhrinke to doe you ſeruice, I ſhal no • eſt • e •
• my life a waightier matter then indeed it is, I • n • w tis ſubi • ct to more chances then it hath hou • es, and I were better looſe it in my King • cauſe, then with an • gue. or fall, or ſleepin • to a thi •• e; as all theſe are • ro • able eno • g • : let me • ut know • ha • I ſhal do foryou.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: It will not out: were you with Gobrius,
And bad him giue my ſiſter all content
The place affoords, and giue her leaue to ſend
And ſpeake to whom ſhee pleaſe?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir▪ I was.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: And did you to Bacurius ſay as much
About Tigranes?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Thats all my buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: O ſay not ſo,
You had an anſwere of all this before,
Beſides, I th n • e this buſineſſe might be vtterd
More careleſlie.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come, thou ſhalt haue it out; I doe beſeech thee
By all the loue thou haſt profeſt to me,
To ſee my Siſter from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: VVell, and what?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Thats all.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: That's ſtrange, ſhall I ſay nothing to her?

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: Not a word;
But if thou loueſt me, find ſome ſubtill way
To make her vnſterſtand by ſignes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But what▪ what ſ • o • ld I make her vnderſtand?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O Mardonius, for that I muſt be pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You may, but I can onelie ſee her then.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Tis true;
Beare her this ring then, and on more aduice
Thou ſhalt ſpeake to her: Tell her I doe loue
My kindred all; wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Mar▪
sp.p: Is there no more?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O yes, and her the beſt;
Better then any brother loues his ſiſter: That's all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Me thinkes this
Neede not haue beene deliuered with ſuch caution;
Ile doe it.

sp.speaker: Arb:
sp.l: There is more yet,
VVilt thou be faithfull to me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir▪ if I take vpon me to deliuer it,
After I heare it, He paſſe through fire to doe it▪

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I loue her better then a brother ought;
Doſt thou conce • ue me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope I doe not Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, thou art dull, kneele downe before her▪
And nere riſe againe, till ſhee will loue me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: VVhy, I thinke ſhee does.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But better then ſhee does, another way;
As wiues loue Husbands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, I thinke there are few wiues that loue their
Husbands better then ſhee does you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou wilt not vnderſtand me: is it fit
This ſhould bee vtterd plainl • e; take it then
Naked as it is: I would deſire her loue
Laſciuiouſlie, leudlie, inceſtuouſlie,
To doe a ſinne that needs muſt damne vs both;
And thee to▪ Doſt thou vnderſtand me now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, there's your Ring againe; what haue I done
Diſhoneſtlie in my whole life, name it▪
That you ſhould put ſo baſe a buſineſſe to me?

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: Didſt thou not tell mee thou wouldſt doe it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes▪ if I vndertooke it; but if all
My heires were liues, I would not be ingag'd
In ſuch a cauſe • o ſaue my laſt life.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O guilt, how poore, and weake a thing art thou?
This man that is my ſeruant, whom my breath
Might blow about the world, might beate me here
Hauing his cauſe, whilſt I preſt downe with ſinne
Could not reſiſt him, deare Mardonius
It was a motion misbeſeeming man.
And I am ſorrie for it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray God you may be ſo: you muſt vnderſtand, nothing that you can vtter, can remooue my loue and ſeruice from my Prince. But otherwiſe, I thinke I ſhall not loue you more. For you are ſinnefull, and if you doe this crime, you ought to haue no lawes. For after this it will bee great iniuſtice in you to puniſh any offendor for any crime: For my ſelfe I find my heart too bigge, I feele I haue not patience to looke on whilſt you runne theſe forbidden courſes: Meanes I haue none but your Fauour, and I am • ather glad, that I ſhall looſe vm both together▪ then keepe vm with ſuch conditions, I ſhall find a dwelling amongſt ſome people, where though our garments perhaps be courſer, we ſhall be richer • arre within, and harbor no ſuch vices in vm. God preſerue you, and mend you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Mardonius, ſtay Mardonius, For though
My preſ • nt ſtate require nothing but knau • s
To be about me, ſuch as are prepar'd
For euery wicked act▪ yet who does know
But that my loathed Fate may turne about,
And I haue vſe of honeſt men againe:
I hope I may, I prethy leaue me not.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Maieſtie, ther's the knife.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What knife:

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: The Sword is eaten.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Away you Foole▪ the King is ſerious,
And cannot now admit your vanities.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Vanities, I am no honeſt man if my enemies haue not brought it to this, what, doe you thinke I lie?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No, no, tis well Beſſus, tis very well,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad ont'.
If your enemies brought it to that, your enemies are cutlers,
Come, leaue the King.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: No, let him ſtay Mardonius, let him ſtay,
I haue occaſions with him very weightie,
And I can ſpare you now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why I can ſpare you now.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Mardonius giue way to the ſtate affayres

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed you are fitter for his preſent purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Beſſus I ſhould imploy thee; wilt thou do't

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Doe for you, by this ayre I will doe any thing without exception, be it a good, bad, or indifferent thing▪

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Do not ſweare.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: By this light but I will,
Any thing whatſoeuer.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But I ſhall name a thing
Thy conſcience will not ſuffer thee to doe.

sp.speaker: Beſ▪
sp.p: I would faine heare that thing.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why I would haue thee get my Siſter for me:
Thou vnderſtands me in a wicked manner.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: O you would haue about with her?
Ile do't, Ile do't Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Wilt thou, doſt make no more ant?

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: More, no, why is there any thing elſe, if there be tell me, it ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Haſt thou no greater ſence of ſuch a ſinne?
Thou art too wicked for my company
Though I haue hell within me, and mayſt yet
Corrupt me further: pray thee anſwere me
How doe I ſhew to thee after this motion?

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: VVhy your Maieſtie lookes as well in my opinion as euer you did ſince you were borne:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But thou appeareſt to me after thy grant
The vglieſt, loathed, deteſtable thing
That I haue euer met with. Thou haſt eyes
Like flames of Sulphur, which me thinkes doe dart
Infection on me, and thou haſt a mouth
Enough to take me in, where there doe ſtand
Fower rowes of Iron teeth.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p:
I feele no ſuch thing, but tis no matter how I looke, Jle doe your buſineſſe as well as they that looke better, and
when this is diſpatcht, if you haue a minde to your Mother tell me, and you ſhall ſee Ile ſet it hard:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: My Mother, Heauen forgiue me to heare this,
I am inſpir'd with horror: I hate thee
Worſe then my ſinne, which if I could come by,
Should ſuffer death eternall, nere to riſe
In any breaſt againe. Know I will die
Languiſhing mad, as I reſolue I ſhall,
Ere I will deale by ſuch an Inſtrument:
Thou art too ſinfull to imploy in this;
Out of the world, away.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: What doe you meane Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Hung round with curſes, take thy fearefull flight into the deſarts, where mongſt all the monſters,
If thou findſt one fo beaſtly as thy ſelfe,
Thou ſhalt be held as innocent.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: If there were no ſuch Inſtruments as thou,
We Kings could neuer act ſuch wicked deeds:
Seeke out a man that mockes Diuinitie,
That breakes each precept both of Gods and Mans,
And Natures too, and does it without luſt;
Me • rely becauſe it is a law, and good,
And liue with him: for him thou canſt not ſpoile.
Away I ſay; I will not doe this ſinne.
Ile preſſe it here till it doe breake my breaſt;
It heaues to get out: but thou art a ſinne
And ſpight of torture, I wil keep thee in.

div.head: Actus Quarti Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: HAue you written Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes, good Gobrias.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: And with a kindneſſe, and ſu • h winning words
As may prouoke him at one inſtant fee e
His double fault, your wrong, and his owne raſhneſſe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I haue ſent words enough, if words may winne him
From his diſpleaſure, and ſuch words I hope
As ſhall gaine much vpon his goodneſſe, Gobrius:
Yet fearing ſince th'are many, and a womans,
A poore beliefe may follow; I haue wouen
As many truthes within vm to ſpeake for me,
That if he be but gracious, and receiue vm.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Good Ladie, be not fearefull; if he ſhould not
Gi • e vou your preſent end in this beleeue it
You ſha l feele (if your vertue can induce you
To labour out this tem • eſt, which I know
Is but a poore proofe • gainſt your patience▪)
All thoſe contents your ſpirit will arriue at
Newer and ſweeter to you; your royall brother
(VVhen he ſhall once collect himſelfe, and ſee
How farre • e 〈◊〉 beene aſunder from himſelfe,
What a meere ſtranger to his golden temper)
M • ſt from thoſe rootes of vertue, (neuer dying
Though ſomewhat ſtopt with humour) ſhoote againe
Into a thouſand glories bearing his fa re branches
Hie as our hopes can looke at ſtraight as Iuſtice,
Loden with ri e contents: he loues you dearely,
I know it, and I hope I neede not further
Winne you to vnderſtand it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I beleeue it,
Howſoeuer I am ſure I loue him dearely,
So dearely, that if any thing I write
Heauen • e a • itneſſe with mee, and my faith
I had rather liue in • omb'd here.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You ſhall not feele a vorſe ſtroke then your griefe, I am ſorr • tis ſo ſharpe: I kiſſe your hand, and this night will deliuer this true ſtorie with this hand to your brother.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Peace goe with you,

You are a good man; my
• paconia
VVhy are you euer ſad thus?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: O deere Ladie.

〈2 pages missing〉
Many, and ſtrange ones,
I feele my olde fire flame againe, and burne
So ſtrong and violent, that ſhould I ſee her
Againe, the griefe, and that would kill me 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Your token I acknowledge, you may paſſe;
There is the King.

sp.speaker: Spac.
sp.p: I thanke your Lordſhip for it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Shee comes, ſhee comes, ſhame hide me euer from her; would I were buried, or ſo farre remou'd
Light might not find me out: I dare not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Spac.
sp.l: Nay, neuer hide your ſelfe; for were you hid
vvhere earth hides all her riches, nere her center;
My wrongs without more day would light me to you:
I muſt ſpeake ere I die; were all your greatneſſe
Doubled vpon you, y'are a periur'd man,
And onely mighty in the wickedneſſe
Of wronging women. Thou art ſalfe, falſe Prince,
I liue to ſee it: poore Spaconia liues
To tell thee thou art falſe; and then no more:
Shee liues to tell thee thou art more vnconſtant
Then all ill women euer were together;
Thy faith as firme as raging ouerflowes,
That no banke can command; and as laſting
As boyes gay bubbles blowne in the aire, and broken:
The wind is fixt to thee, and ſooner ſhall
The beaten Marriner with his ſhrill whiſtle,
Calme the loude murmurs of the troubled maine,
And ſtrike it ſmooth againe; then thy ſoule fall
To haue peace in loue with any: Thou art all
That all good men muſt hate, and if thy ſtorie
Shall tell ſucceeding ages what thou wert,
O let it ſpare me in it, leſt true Louers
In pitty of my wrongs burne thy blacke legend,
And with their curſes ſhake thy ſleeping aſhes.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Oh, oh:
The deſtinies I hope haue pointed out
Our ends alike, that thou maiſt die for loue,
Though not for me: for this aſſure thy ſelfe,
The Princeſſe hates thee deadly, and will ſooner
Be wonne to marrie with a Bull, and ſafer,
Then ſuch a beaſt as thou art: I haue ſtrucke
I feare too deepe; beſhrow me fort: Sir,
This ſorrow workes me like a cunning friendſhip,
Into the ſame piece with it; hee's aſham'd,
Alas▪ I haue beene too rugged: Deare my Lord,
I am ſorrie I haue ſpoken any thing,
Indeed I am, that may adde more reſtraint
To that too much you haue: Good Sir be pleaſ'd
To thinke it was a fault of loue, not malice;
And doe as I will doe: forgiue it Prince,
I doe, and can forgiue the greateſt ſinnes
To me you can repent of; pray belieue▪me.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: O my Spaconia! O thou vertuous woman!

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: No more, the King Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Haue you beene carefull of our noble Priſoner
That he want nothing fitting for his greatneſſe?

sp.speaker: Bac▪
sp.p: I hope his grace will quit me, for my care Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Tis well, royall Tigranes health.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: More then the ſtricktneſſe of this place can giue Sir I offer backe againe to great Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: VVe thanke you worthy Prince, and pray excuſe vs,
We haue not ſeene you ſince your being here,
I hope your noble vſage has beene equall
With your owne Perſon: your impriſonment
If it be any, I dare ſay is eafie,
And ſhall not outlaſt two dayes.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: I thanke you:
My vſage here has beene the ſame it was
Worthy a royall Conquerour. For my reſtraint
It came vnkindly, becauſe much vnlookt for;
But I muſt beare it:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: VVhat Lady is that Bacurius?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: One of the Princeſſe women Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I feard it: why comes ſhee hether!

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: To ſpeake with the Prince Tigranes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From whom Bacurius?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: From the Princeſſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I know I had ſeene her.

sp.speaker: Mardo.
sp.l: His fit beginnes to take him now againe
Tis a ſtrange Feauer, and twill ſhake vs all
sp.p: Anone I feare; would he were well cur'd of this raging folly: Giue me the warres, where men are mad, and may talke what they liſt, and held the braueſt Fellowes; This pelting pratling peace is good for nothing: drinking's a vertue to it:

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I ſee theres truth in no man, nor obedience,
But for his owne ends, why did you let her in?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: It was your owne command to barre none from him,
Beſide the Princeſſe ſent her Ring Sir
For my warrant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: A token to Tigranes, did ſhe not:
Sirra tell truth.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: I doe not vſe to lye Sir,
Tis no way I eate or liue by, and I thinke
This is no token Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This combat has vndone him: If he had beene well beaten, he had beene temperate: I ſhal neuer ſee him hanſome againe, till he haue a Horſe-mans ſtaffe poak't through his ſhoulders, or an arme broke with a Bullet.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I am trifled with.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I know it, as I know thee to be falſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now the clap comes.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: You neuer knew me ſo Sir, I dare ſpeake it,
And durſt a worſe man tell me though my better.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Tis well ſaid by my Soule.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: Sirra you anſwere as you had no life.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That I feare Sir to looſe nobly.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: I ſay Sir once againe

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You may ſay Sir what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: would I might doe ſo.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will Sir, and ſay openly this woman carries letters, by my life I know ſhe carries letters, this woman does it:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
VVould Beſſus were here to take her aſide and ſearch
her, he would quickly tell you what ſhe carried Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I haue found it out, this woman carries letters.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: If this hold twill be an ill world for Bauds, Chamber-maids, and poſt-boyes, I thanke God I haue none but his letters pattents, things of his owne inditing.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: Prince this cunning cannot doe it.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: VVhat Sir, I reach you not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It ſhall not ſerue your turne Prince.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Serue my turne Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.p: • Sir it ſhall not ſerue your turne.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Be plainer good Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: This woman ſhall carry no more letters backe to your loue Panthaea, by heauen ſhe ſhall not, I ſa ſhe ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Mardo.
sp.p: This would make a Saint ſweare like a Souldier, and a Souldier like termogant.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: This beates me more King then the blowes you gaue me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Take vm away both, and together let vm be priſoners, ſtricktly and cloſely kept, or Sirra your life ſhall anſwere it; and let no bodie ſpeake with vm hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Well I am ſubiect to you, and muſt endure theſe paſſions.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: This is the impriſonment I haue lookt for alwayes, and the deare place I would chuſe.
sp.stage: Ex. Bacu. with Tig. and Spa.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, haue you done well now?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Dare you reproue it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You muſt be croſſing me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I haue no letters Sir to anger you,
But a dry ſonnet of my Corporals
To an old Sadlers wife, and that Ile burne Sir:
Tis like to proue a fine age for the Ignorant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: How dareſt thou ſo often forfeit thy life,
Thou knoweſt tis in my power to take it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, and I know you wonnot, or if you doe, youle miſſe it quicklie.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who ſhall then tell you of theſe childiſh follies
When I am dead? Who ſhall put to his power
To draw thoſe vertues out of a floud of humours
Where they are drownd, and make vm ſhine againe?
No cut my head off: doe, kill me:
Then you may talke, and be beleeud, and grow,
And haue your too ſelfe-glorious temper rot ••
Into a dead ſleepe, and the kingdome with you,
Like forraigne ſwords be in your throats, and ſlaughter
Be euery where about you like your flatterers.
Doe, kill me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Prethee be tamer good Mardonius,
Thou knowſt I loue thee, nay I honour thee:
Beleeue it good old Souldier I am all thine:
But I am rackt cleane from my ſelfe, beare with me,
Woot thou beare with me good Mardonius.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There comes a good man, loue him too, hees temperate,
You may liue to haue need of ſuch a vertue,
Rage is not ſtill in faſhion.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: VVelcome good Gobrius.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: My ſeruice, and this letter to your grace.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: From the rich mine of vertue, and all beautie,
Your mournefull Siſter.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is in priſon Gobrius, is ſhee not?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: She is Sir till your pleaſure doe enlarge her,
Which on my knees I beg; O tis not fit
That all the ſweetneſſe of the world in one;
The youth, and vertue, that would haue wilde Tygers
And wilder people, that haue knowne no manners
Should liue thus Cloyſterd vp, For your loues ſake
(If there be any in that Noble heart)
To her a wretched Ladie, and forlorne,
Or for her loue to you, (which is as much
As Nature, and obedience euer gaue)
Haue pittie on her beauties.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Prethee ſtand vp, tis true ſhe is too Faire,
And all theſe commendations but her owne:
VVould thou hadſt neuer ſo commended her,
Or I nere liu'd to haue heard it, Gobrius;
If thou but knew of the wrong her beautie does her,
Thou wouldſt in pittie of her be a lyar:
Thy ignorance has drawne me wretched man
VVhether my ſelfe nor thou canſt well tell, O my Fate,
I thinke ſhee loues me; but I feare another
Is deeper in her heart: how thinkſt thou Gobrius?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: I doe beſeech your Grace beleeue it not,
For let me periſh if it be not falſe:
Good Sir reade her letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This loue, or what a diuell is it, I know not, begets more miſchiefe then a wake. I had rather be we I beaten ſtaru'd, or lowſie, then liue within the aire ont. He that had ſeene this braue fellow charge through a groue of pykes but tother day, and looke vpon him now, will nere beleeue his eyes againe; If he continue thus but two daies more, a Taylor may beat him with one hand tyed behind him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Alas ſhe would be at libertie,
And there be thouſand reaſons Gobrius
That will denie it:
Which if ſhe knew, ſhe would contentedly
Be where ſhe is and bleſſe her vertue for it,
And me though ſhe were cloſer, She would Gobrius,
Good man indeed ſhe would.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Then good Sir for her ſatisfaction
Send for her, and with reaſon make her know
VVhy ſhe muſt liue thus from you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will goe bring her to me.

div.stage: Enter Beſſus, and two Sword-men, and a Boy.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.l: Y' are verie welcome both, ſome ſtooles there boy,
And reach a Table; Gentlemen oth' Sword,
Pray ſit without more complement: be gone childe,
I haue beene curious in the ſearching of you,
Becauſe I vnderſtood you wiſe, and valiant perſons.

sp.p: vve vnderſtand our ſelues Sir.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.l: Nay Gentlemen, and my deare friends oth' Sword,
No complement I pray; but to the cauſe
I hang vpon, which in few, is my honour.
You cannot hang too much Sir for your honour,
But to your cauſe, be wiſe, and ſpeake truth.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: My firſt doubt is my beating by my Prince.

sp.l: Stay there a little Sir, doe you doubt a beating,
Or haue you had a beating by your Prince.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Gentlemen ath'ſword, my Prince has beaten me.
Brother what thinke you of this caſe
If he haue beaten him, the caſe is cleare.

sp.l: If he haue beaten him I grant the caſe;
But how? VVe cannot be too ſubtill in this buſineſſe
I ſay, but how?

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Euen with his royall hand.
Was it a blow of loue or indignation.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: T was twentie blowes of indignation gentlemen,
Beſides two blowes ath'face.
Thoſe blowes ath'face haue made a new caſe ont',
The reſt were but an honourable rud • neſſe▪

sp.p: Two blowes oth'face, and giuen by a worſe man, I muſt confeſſe as we Sword-men ſay, had turnd the buſineſſe: Marke me brother, by a worſe man; but being by his Prince, had they beene ten, and thoſe ten drawne ten teeth, beſide the hazard of his noſe for euer; all theſe had beene but fauours: This is my flat opinion, which Ile die in.

The King may doe much Captaine beieeue it, for had hee crackt your skull through like a bottle, or broke a rib or two with croſſing of you, yet you had loſt no honour: This is ſtrange you may imagin; but this is truth now Captaine.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: I will be glad to imbrace it gentleman;
But how farre may he ſtrike me?
Theres another,
A new cauſe riſing from the time, and diſtance,
In which I will deliuer my opinion:
sp.p: He may ſtrike, beate, or cauſe to be beaten; for theſe are naturall to man: your Prince I ſay may beate you ſo farre forth as his dominion reacheth; that's for the diſtance, the time, ten mile a day▪ I take it.

sp.l: Brother you erre, tis fifteene mile a day,
His ſtage is ten, his beatings are fifteene.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: Tis a the longeſt, but we ſubiects muſt
Be ſubiect to it: you are wiſe, and vertuous.
Obedience euer makes that noble vſe ont,
To which I dedicate my beaten bodie;
I muſt trouble you a little further Gentlemen oth' Sword.
No trouble at all to vs Sir, if we may
Profit your vnderſtanding; we are bound
By vertue of ou • calling, to vtter our opinions
Shortly, and diſ • reetly.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: My ſoreſt buſineſſe is, I haue beene kickt.
How farre Sir?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Not to ſlatter my ſelfe in it all ouer, my ſword forſt, but not loſt; for diſ • reetely I renderd it to ſaue that imputation.
It ſhewed diſcretion the beſt part of valour.

sp.l: Brother, this is a pretty caſe, pray ponder on't,
Our friend here has beene kickt.

sp.p: He has ſo brother.

sp.l: Sorely he ſayes: Now had he ſit downe here
Vpon the meere kicke, it had beene cowardly.

sp.p: I thinke it had beene cowardly indeed.

sp.l: But our friend has r • d •• m'd it, in deliuering
His ſword without compulſion; and that man
That tooke it of him, I pronounce a weake one,
And his kicks nullities.
He ſhould haue kickt him after the deliuerie,
Which is the confirmation of a coward.
Brother, I take it you miſtake the queſtion:
For ſay that I were kickt.
I muſt not ſay ſo;
Nor I muſt not heare it ſpoke byth' tongue of man
You kickt deare brother; you are merrie.

sp.p: But put the caſe I were kickt?
Lot them put it that are things wearie of their liues, & know not honour: put caſe you were kickt?
I doe not ſay I was kickt.
Nor no ſilly creature, that weares his head without a caſe, his ſoule in a skin-coate: you kickt deare brother.

sp.speaker: Beſſ▪
sp.l: Nay Gentlemen, let vs doe what we ſhall doe
Truly and honeſtly; good Sit toth' queſtion.

sp.p: Why then I ſay, ſuppoſe your boy kickt Captaine?
The boy may be ſuppoſ'd, hee's lyable; but kicke my brother?

sp.l: A fooliſh forward zeale Sir in my friend;
But to the boy, ſuppoſe the boy were kickt?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: I doe ſuppoſe it.
Has your boy a ſword?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Surely no: I pray ſuppoſe a ſword too.
I doe ſuppoſe it: you grant your boy was kickt then.
By no meanes Captaine, let it be ſuppoſ'd ſtill; this word grant, makes not for vs.
I ſay this muſt be granted.
This muſt be granted brother?
I, this muſt be granted.
Still the muſt:
I ſay this muſt be granted.
Giue me the muſt againe, ag • ine; brother you palter.
I will not heare you waſpe.
Brother, I ſay you palter, the muſt three times together; I weare as ſharpe ſteele as another man,
sp.l: And my Foxe bites as deepe, muſt •• my deare brother:
But to the cauſe againe:

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Nay, looke you Gentlemen.
In a word I ha done.

sp.l: A tall man, but vntemperate; tis great pittie:
Once more ſuppoſe the boy kickt.

sp.p: Forward.
And being throughly kickt, laughes at the kicker▪
So much for vs; proceede.

sp.l: And in this beaten ſcorne, as I may call it,
Deliuers vp his weapon: where lies the error?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.l: It lies ith beating Sir,
I found it foure dayes ſince.
The error, and a ſore one, as I take it;
Lies in the thing kicking.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: I vnderſtand that well, tis ſore indeed Sir.
That is according to the man that did it.
There ſprings a new branch: whoſe was the foo • e?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Ah Lords.

sp.l: The cauſe is mightie, but had it beene two Lords,
And both had kickt you, if you laught, tis cleere.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.l: I did laugh,
But how will that helpe me Gentlemen?

sp.p: Yes, it ſhall helpe you, if you laught alowd.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: As lowd as a kickt man could laugh, I laught Sir:

sp.l: My reaſon now; the valiant man is knowne
By ſuffering and contemning, you haue
Enough of both, and you are valiant.
If he be ſure he has beene kickt enough:
For that braue ſufferance you ſpeake of brother,
Conſiſts not in a beating, and away,
But in a cudgeld bodie, from eighteene
To eight and thirtie: in a head rebuk't
With pots of all Size, daggers, ſtooles, and bedſtaues,
This ſhewes a valiant man.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: Then I am valiant, as valiant, as the proudeſt,
For theſe are all familiar things to me:
Familiar as my ſleepe, or want of money.
All my whole bodi's but one bruize with beating,
I thinke I haue beene cudgeld with all nations,
And almoſt all Religions.
Imbrace him brother, this man is valiant,
I know it by my ſelfe hees valiant.
Captaine thou art a valiant Gentleman
To abide vpon't, a very valiant man.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: My equall friends ath'ſword, I muſt requeſt your hands to this.
Tis fit it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.l: Boy get ſome wine, and pen and inke within:
Am I cleare Gentlemen?
Sir when the world has taken notice what we haue done,
Make much of your bodie, for Ile pawne my ſteele,
Men will be coyer of their legs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: I muſt requeſt you goe along, and teſtifie to the Lord Bacurius, whoſe foot has ſtrucke me, how you find my cauſe.

sp.l: We will, and tell that Lord he muſt be rul'd,
Or there be thoſe abroad will rule his Lordſhip.

div.stage: Enter Arbaces at ōne doore, Gob▪ and Panth • ea at another▪

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir her's the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Leaue vs then alone.
For the maine cauſe of her impriſonment
Muſt not be heard by any but her ſelfe:
You are welcome Siſter, and I would to God
I could ſo bid you by another name,
If you aboue loue not ſuch ſinnes as theſe▪
Circle my heart with thoughts as cold as ſnow
To quench theſe riſing flames that harbour here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Sir, does it pleaſe you, I ſhould ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Pleaſe me,
I more then all the art of Muſicke can;
Thy ſpeech does pleaſe me, for it euer ſounds
As thou broughts ioyfull vnexpected newes:
And yet it is not fit thou ſhould • t be heard,
I prethee thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Be it ſo, I will.
I am the firſt that euer had a wrong
So farre from being fit to haue redreſſe,
That twas vnfit to heare it; I will backe
To priſon rather, then diſquiet you,
And waite till it be fit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, doe not goe,
For I will heare thee with a ſerious thought:
I haue collected all thats man about me
Together ſtrongly, and I am reſolud
To heare the • largely, but I doe beſeech thee
Doe not come neerer to me, for there is
Something in that that will vndo • vs both.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas Sir, am I venom?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Yes to me.
Though of thy ſelfe I thinke thee to be in
As equall a degree of heate, • r cold
As Nature can make, yet as •• ſound men
Conuert the ſweeteſt, and the nouriſhingſt meates
Into diſeaſes, ſo ſhall I diſtemperd,
Doe thee, I prethe • draw no • eerer to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir this is that I would, I am of late,
Shut from the world, and why it ſhould be thus
Is all I wiſh to know.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: VVhy credit me
Panthaea, credit me that am thy brother,
Thy louing brother, that there is a cauſe
Sufficient, vet vnfit for thee to knowe,
That might vndoe thee eu • rlaſtingly
Onely to hear • , wilt thou b •• credit this;
By heauen • is true, b • leeu • it if thou can • t.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l:
Children a ••
• oo •• s are e • e • credulous;
And I am both I thi • ke, for I b • l • eue:
If you diſſemble be it on your head,
Ile backe vnto my • riſon▪ yet me thinkes
I might be kept in ſome place where you are:
For in my ſelfe • finde, I know not what
To call it, but it is a great deſire
To ſee you often.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Fie, you come in a ſtep, what doc you meane
Deare Siſter▪ doe not ſo: Alas Pa • thaea,
Where I am, would you be, why thats the cauſe
You are impriſond, that you may not be
VVhere I am.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Then I muſt endure it Sir, God keepe you.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.l: Nay, you ſhall heare the cauſe in ſhort Panthaea;
And when thou hearſt it, thou wilt bluſh for me,
And hang thy head downe like a Violet
Full of the mornings dew: There is a way
To gaine thy freedome, but tis ſuch a one
As puts thee in worſe bondage, and I know,
Thou wouldſt encounter fire, and make a proofe
Whether the Gods haue care of innocents,
Rather then follow it; know I haue lo • t
The onely difference betwixt man, and beaſt,
My reaſon.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Heauen forbid.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Nay it is gone,
And I am left as farre without a bound,
As the wild Ocean that obeyes the winds;
Each ſuddai • e paſſ • on throwes me as it lifts,
And ouerwhelmes all that oppoſe my will:
I haue beheld thee with a luſtfull eye:
My heart is ſet on wickedneſſe, to act
Such ſinnes with thee, as I haue beene afraid
To thinke off: If thou dar'ſt conſent to this,
(Which I beſeech thee doe not) thou maiſt gaine
Thy libertie, and yeeld me a content:
If not thy dwelling muſt be darke, and cloſe
VVhere I may neuer ſee thee; For God knowes
That layd this puniſhment vpon my pride,
Thy ſight at ſome time will enforce my madneſſe
To make a ſtart eye to thy rauiſhing:
Now ſpit vpon me, and call all reproaches
Thou canſt deuiſe together; and at once
Hurle vm againſt me: for I am a ſickneſſe
As killing as the plague, ready to ſeize thee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Farre be it from me to r • uile the King:
But it is true, that I ſhould rather chuſe
To ſearch out death, that elſe would ſearch out me,
And in a graue ſleepe with my innocence,
Then welcome ſuch a ſinne: It is my fate,
To theſe croſſe accidents I was ordaind,
And muſt haue patience; and but that my eyes
Haue more of woman in vm then my heart,
I would not weepe: peace enter you againe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Farewell, and good Panthaea pray for me;
Thy prayers are pure, that I may find a death,
How euer ſoone before my paſſions grow,
That they forget, what I deſire, is ſinne;
For thether they are tending: If that happen,
Then I ſhall force thee, though thou wert a Virgin
By vow to Heauen, and ſhall pull a heape
Of ſtrange▪ yet vninuented ſinnes vpon me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir, I will pray for you▪ yet you ſhall know
It is a ſullen • ate that gouernes vs.
For I could wiſh as heartilie as you
I were no ſiſter to you▪ I ſhould then
Imbrace your lawfull loue ſooner then health.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Couldſt • hou affect me then?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So perfectly
That as it is, I nere ſhall ſway my heart
To like another.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Then I curſe my birth,
Muſt this be added to my miſeries
That thou art willing too, Is there no ſteppe
To our full happine • ſe, but theſe meere ſounds
Brother and Siſter.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: There is nothing elſe
But theſe alas will ſeperate vs more
Then twentie worlds betwixt vs.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I haue liu'd
To conquer men, and now am ouerthrowne
Onely by words, Brother and Siſter: where
Haue thoſe words dwelling? I will find vm out
And vtterly deſtroy them, but they are
Not to be graſp't▪ let vm be men or beaſts,
And I will cut vm from the earth, or townes,
And I will raſe vm, and then blow vm vp:
Let vm be Seas, and I will drinke them off,
And yet haue vnquencht fire left in my breaſt:
Let vm be any thing but meerely voice▪

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But tis not in the power of any Force
Or pollicie to conquer them.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Panthaea,
VVhat ſhall wee doe? ſhall we ſtand firmely here, and gaze our eyes out?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Would I could doe ſo;
But I ſhall weepe out mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Accurſed man,
Thou boughtſt thy reaſon at too deare a rate;
For thou haft all thy actions bounded in
With curious rules, when cuerie Beaſt is free:
What is there that acknowledges a kindred
But wretched Man? Who euer ſaw the Bull
Fearefully leaue the Heifer that he likt,
Becauſe they had one Dam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir, I diſturbe you,
And my ſelfe too; twere better I were gone:
I will not be ſo fooliſh as I was.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Stay, we will loue iuſt as becomes our birthes,
No otherwiſe: Brothers and Siſters may
VValke hand in hand together; ſo will we
Come neerer: Is there any hurt in this?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Faith theres none at all:
And tell me truly now, is there not one
You loue aboue me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No by Heauen.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Yet you ſent vnto Tigranes Siſter.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: True, but for another: for the truth—

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: No more,
Ile credit thee; I know thou canſt not lie,
Thou art all truth.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But is there nothing elſe
That we may doe, but onely walke; me thinkes
Brothers and ſiſters lawfully may kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And ſo they may Panthaea, ſo will we,
And kiſſe againe too; we were ſcrupulous
And fooliſh, but we will be ſo no more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: If you haue any mercy, let me goe
To priſon, to my death, to any thing:
I feele a ſinne growing vpon my bloud,
Worſe then all theſe, hotter I feare then yours.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That is impoſſible, what ſhould we doe?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Flie • it for Gods ſake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: So we muſt, away;
Sin growes vpon vs more by this delay.

div.head: Actus Quinti Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: SIR, the King has ſeene your Commiſſion, and • eleeu • s it, and freely by this warrant giues you leaue to viſit Prince Tigranes your noble Maſter.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: I thanke his Grace, and kiſſe his hanes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But is the maine of all your buſineſſe Ended in this?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: I haue another, but a worſe; I am aſham'd, it is a buſineſſe.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You ſerue a worthy perſon, and a ſtranger I am ſure you are; you may imploy mee if you pleaſe, without your purſe, ſuch Office ſhould euer be their owne rewards.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: I am bound to your nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I may haue neede of you, and then this curteſie,
If it be any, is not ill beſtowed:
But may I ciuilly deſire the reſt?
I ſhall not be a hurter, if no helper.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Sir, you ſhall know I haue loſt a fooliſh daughter,
And with her all my patience; pilferd away,
By a meane Captaine of your Kings.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay there Sir:
If he haue reacht the noble worth of Captaine,
He may well claime a worthy gentlewoman,
Though ſhee were yours, and noble.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: I grant all that too: but this wretched fellow
Reaches no further then the emptie name,
That ſerues to feede him; were he valiant,
Or had but in him any noble nature,
That might hereafter promiſe him a good man;
My carcs were ſomething lighter, and my graue
A ſpan yet from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I confeſſe ſuch fellowes
Be in all royall Campes, and haue, and muſt be
To make the 〈◊〉 of coward more deteſted
In the meane Souldier, that with ſuch a foyle
Sets of much valour: By deſcription
I ſhould now gueſſe him to you. It was Beſſus,
I dare almoſt with confidence pronounce it.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Tis ſuch a ſcuruy name as Beſſus, and now I thinke tis hee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Captaine, doe you call him?
Beleeue me Sir, you haue a miſerie
Too mighty for your age: A pox vpon him,

〈2 pages missing〉
You a valiant fellow for all this.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: My daughter is a Whore,
I feele it now too ſencible; yet I will ſee her,
Diſcharge my ſelfe of being Father to her,
And then backe to my Countrie, and there die;
Farewell Captaine.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Farewell Sir, farewell, commend me to the Gentlewoman I pr • ia.
How now Captaine, beare vp man.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: Gentlemen ath'ſword your hands once more, I haue Beene kickt againe, but the fooliſh fellow is penitent,
Has ask't me mercy, and my honor's ſafe.
VVe knew that, or the fooliſh fellow had better a kick't His Grandſire.
Confirme, confirme I pray.

sp.p: There be our hands againe.

sp.l: Now let him come, and ſay he was not ſorry,
And he ſleepes for it.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: Alas good ignorant old man, let him goe,
Let him goe, theſe courſes will vndoe him.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: My Lord your authoritie is good, and I am glad it is ſo, for my confent would neuer hinder you from ſeeing your owne King. I am a Miniſter, but not a gouernour of this ſtate; yonder is your King, Ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: There he is indeed,
And with him my diſloyall childe.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: I doe perceiue my fault ſo much, that yet
Me thinkes thou ſhouldſt not haue forgiuen me.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Health to your Maieſtie.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: VVhat? good Ligones, welcome; what buſineſſe brought thee hether?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Seuerall Buſineſſes.
My publique buſineſſe will appeare by this:
I haue a meſſage to deliuer, which
If it pleaſe you ſo to authoriſe, is
An embaſſage from the Armenian ſtate;
Vnto Arbaces for your libertie▪
The offer's there ſet downe, pleaſe you to read it.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: There is no alteration happened
Since I came thence?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: None Sir, all is as it was.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: And all our friends are well.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: All verie well.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Though I haue done nothing but what was good,
I dare not ſee my Father: It was fault
Enough not to acquaint him with that good.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Madam I ſhould haue ſeene you.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O good Sir forgiue me.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Forgiue you, why I am no kin to you, am I?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Should it be meaſur'd by my meane deſerts,
Indeed you are not.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Thou couldſt prate vnhappily
Ere thou couldſt goe, would thou couldſt doe as well.
And how does your cuſtome hold out here.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Are you in priuate ſtill, or how?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Lig
sp.p: Doe you take money? are you come to ſell ſinne yet? perhaps I can helpe you to liberall Clients: or has not the King caſt you off yet? O thou vild creature, whoſe beſt commendation is, that thou art a young VVhore. I would thy Mother had liu'd to ſee this: or rather would I had dyed ere I had ſeene it: why did'ſt not make me acquainted when thou were firſt reſolu'd to be a Who • e? I would haue ſeene thy hot luſt ſatisfied more priuately. I would haue kept a dancer, and a whole conſort of Muſitions in mine owne houſe, onely to fiddle thee.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir I was neuer whore.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: If thou couldſt not ſay ſo much for thy ſelfe thou ſhouldſt be Carted.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Ligones I haue read it, and like it,
You ſhall deliuer it.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Well Sir I will: but I haue priuate buſines with you.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Speake, what iſt?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: How has my age deſeru'd ſo ill of you,
That you can picke no ſtrumpets in the Land,
But out of my breed.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: Strumpets good Ligones?

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Yes, and I wiſh to haue you know, I ſcorne
To get a Whore for any Prince aliue,
And yet ſcorne will not helpe me thinkes: My daughter
Might haue beene ſpar'd, there were enough beſide.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: May I not proſper, but Shee's innocent
As morning light for me, and I dare ſweare
For all the world.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Why is ſhe with you then?
Can ſhe waite on you better then your men,
Has ſhe a gift in plucking off your ſtockings,
Can ſhe make Cawdles well, or cut your Cornes,
VVhy doe you keepe her with you? For your Queene
I know you doe contemne her, ſo ſhould I
And euery Subiect elſe thinke much at it.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: • et vm thinke much, but tis more firme then earth
Thou ſeeſt thy Queene there.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Then haue I made a faire hand, I cald her Whore,
If I ſhall ſpeake now as her Father, I cannot of uſe
But greatly rejoyce that ſhe ſhall be a Queene: but if
I ſhould ſpeake to you as a Stateſman ſhee were more fit
To be your VVhore.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Get you about your buſineſſe to Arbaces,
Now you talke idlie.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I will goe.
And ſhall ſhe be a Queeue, ſhe had more wit
Then her old Father when ſhe ranne away:
Shall ſhee be a Queene, now by my troth tis fine,
He dance out of all meaſure at her wedding:
Shall I not Sir?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Yes marrie ſhalt thou.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: I'e make theſe witherd Kexes beare my bodie
Two h •• rest gether aboue ground.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Nay, goe▪ my buſineſſe requires haſte.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Good God preſerue you, you are an excellent King.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Farewell good Father.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: Farewell ſweete vertuous Daughter;
Ineuer was ſo Joyfull in my life,
That I remember: ſhall ſhee be a Queene?
Now I perceiue a man may weepe for ioy,
I had thought they had lied that ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: Come my deare loue.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: But you may ſee another
May alter that againe.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.l: Vrge it no more;
I haue made vp a new ſtrong conſtancie,
Not to be ſhooke with eyes; I know I haue
The paſſions of a man, but if I meete
With any ſubiect that ſhall hold my eyes
More firmely then is fit; Ile thinke of thee,
And runne away from it: let that ſuffice.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Three gentlemen without to ſpeake with me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir. Bac. Let them come in.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They are enterd Sir already.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now fellowes, your buſines, are theſe the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: My Lord I haue made bold to bring theſe Gentlemen my Friends ath'ſword along with me.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I am afraid youle fight then.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.l: My good Lord I will not, your Lordſhip is miſtaken,
Feare not Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Sir I am ſorrie fort.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: I can aske no more in honor, Gentlemen you heare my Lord is ſorrie:

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Not that I haue beaten you, but beaten one that will be beaten: one whoſe dull bodie will require launcing: As ſurfeits doe the diet, ſpring and full. Stock-fiſh? Now to your ſwordmen, what come they for good Captaine

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: It ſeemes your Lordſhip has forgot my name.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: No nor your nature neither, though they are things fitter I confeſſe for any thing, then my remembrance, or anie honeſt mans, what ſhall theſe billets doe, be pilde vp in my VVood-yard?

sp.speaker: Beſ
sp.p: Your Lordſhip holds your mirth ſtill, God continue it: but for theſe Gentlemen they come.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: To ſweare you are a Coward, ſpare your Booke, I doe beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip ſtill drawes wide, they come to vouch vnder their valiant hands, I am no Coward.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That would be a ſhew indeed worth ſeeing: ſirra be wiſe and take money for this motion, trauell with it, and where the name of Beſſus has been knowne, or a good Coward ſtirring, twill yeeld more then a tilting. This will proue more beneficiall to you, if you be thriftie, then your Captaineſhip, and more naturall; Men of moſt valiant hands is this true?

sp.l: It is ſo moſt renowned,
Tis ſomewhat ſtrange.

sp.p: Lord, it is ſtrange, yet true; wee haue examined from your Lordſhips foote there to this mans head, the nature of the beatings; and we doe find his honour is come off cleane, and ſufficient: This as our ſwords ſhall helpe vs.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You are much bound to your bilbow-men, I am glad you are ſtraight again Captaine▪ twere good you would thinke ſome way to gratifie them, they haue vndergone a labour for you Beſſus, would haue puzzeld Hercules, with all his valour.
Your Lordſhip muſt vnderſtand we are no men ath' Law, that take pay for our opinions: it is ſufficient wee haue cleer'd our friend.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Yet here is ſomething due, which I as toucht in conſcience will diſcharge Captaine; Ile pay this rent for you.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Spare your ſelfe my good Lord; my braue friends aime at nothing but the vertue.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Thats but a cold diſcharge Sir for their paines.
O Lord▪ my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Be not ſo modeſt, I will giue you ſomething.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: They ſhall dine with your Lordſhip, that's ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Something in hand the while; ye rogues, ye appleſquiers: doe you come hether with your botled valour, your windle frothe, to limit out my beatings.
I doe beſeech your Lordſhip.
O good Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac:
sp.p: Sfoote, what a many of beaten ſlaues are here? get me a cudgell ſirra, and a tough one.
More of your foot, I doe beſeech your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You ſhall, you ſhall dog, and your fellow beagle.
A this ſide good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Off with your ſwords, for if you hurt my foote, Ile haue you fleade you raſcals.
Mines off my Lord.
I beſeech your Lordſhip ſtay a little, my ſtrap's tied to my codpiece point: Now when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Captaine, theſe are your valiant friends, you long for a little too?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: I am verie well, I humblie thanke your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Whats that in your pocket ſlaue, my key you mungrell? thy buttocks cannot be ſo hard, out with't quicklie.
Here tis Sir, a ſmall piece of Artillerie, that a gentleman a deare friend of your Lordſhips ſent me with to get it mended Sir; for if you marke, the noſe is ſomewhat looſe.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: A friend of mine you raſcall, I was neuer wearier of doing nothing, then kicking theſe two foote-bals.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Heres a good cudgell Sir.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: It comes too late; I am wearie, prethee doe thou beate vm.
My Lord this is foule play ifaith, to put a freſh man vpon vs; Men are but men.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That i •• t ſhall ſaue your bones, vp with your rotten regiment, and be gone; I had rather threſh, then be bound to kicke theſe raskals, till they cride hold: Beſſus you may put your hand to them now, and then you are quit. Farewell, as you like this, pray viſit mee againe, twill keepe me in good breath.
Has a diuelliſh hard foote, I neuer felt the like.
Nor I, and yet Ime ſure I ha felt a hundred.
If he kicke thus ith dog-daies, he will be drie founderd: what cure now Captaine, beſides oyle of bayes?

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Why well enough I warrant you, you can goe.
Yes, God be thanked; but I feele a ſhrewd ach, ſure he has ſprang my huckle bone.
I ha loft a haunch.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: A little butter friend, a little butter▪ butter and parſelie is a ſoueraigne matter: probatum eſt.
Captaine, we muſt requeſt your hands now to our honours.

sp.speaker: Beſſ.
sp.p: Yes marrie ſhall ye, and then let all the world come, we are valiant to our ſelues, and theres an end:
Nay, then we muſt be valiant; O my ribbes.
O my ſmall guts, a plague vpon theſe ſharpe toe'd ſhooes, they are murderers.

div.stage: Enter Arbaces with his Sword drawne.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: It is reſolu'd, I bore it whilſt I could,
I can no more, Hell open all thy gates,
And I will thorough them; if they be ſhut,
Ile batter vm, but I will find the place
VVhere the moſt damn'd haue dwelling; ere I end,
Amongſt them all they ſhall not haue a ſinne,
But I may call it mine: I muſt beginne
VVith murder of my friend, and ſo goe on
To an inceſtuous rauiſhing, and end
My life and ſinnes with a forbidden blow
Vpon my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mardo.
sp.l: What Tragedie is nere?
That hand was neuer wont to draw a Sword,
But it cride dead to ſomething:

sp.speaker: Arb. Mar.
sp.p: haue you bid Gobrius come?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How doe you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: vvell, is he comming?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: vvhy Sir are you thus?
why does your hand proclaime a lawleſſe warre
Againſt your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou anſwereſt me one queſtion with another,
Is Gobrius comming?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir he is.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Tis well.
I can forbeare your queſtions then, be gone Sir, I haue markt.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Marke leſſe, it troubles you and me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are more variable then you were.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It may be ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To day no Hermit could be humblier
Then you were to vs all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And now you take new rage into your eies,
As you would looke vs all out of the Land.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe it, will that ſatiſfie,
I prethee get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir I will ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Will ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is my dutie,
I feare you will kill your ſelfe: I am a ſubiect,
And you ſhall doe me wrong in't: tis my cauſe,
And I may ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou art not traind in ſinne,
It ſeemes Mardonius: kill my ſelfe, by heauen
I will not doe it yet; and when I will,
Ile tell thee then: I ſhall be ſuch a creature,
That thou wilt giue me leaue without a word.
There is a method in mans wickedneſſe,
It growes vp by degrees; I am not come
So high as killing of my ſelfe, there are
A hundred thouſand ſinnes twixt me and it,
Which I muſt doe, I ſhall come toot at laſt;
But take my oath not now, be ſatiſfied,
And get thee hence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am ſorrie tis ſo ill.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Be ſorrie then,
True ſorrow is alone, grieue by thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray you let mee ſee your ſword put vp
Before I goe; Ile leaue you then.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why ſo?
What follie is this in thee? is it not
As apt to miſchiefe as it was before?
Can I not reach it thinkeſt thou? theſe are toyes
For children to be pleaſ'd with, and not men;
Now I am ſafe you thinke: I would the booke
Of Fate were here, my ſword is not ſo ſure,
But I ſhould get it out, and mangle that
That all the deſtinies ſhould quite forget
Their fix't decrees, and haſt to make vs new
Farre other Fortunes, mine could not be worſe,
Wilt thou now leaue me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: God put into your boſome temperate thoughts,
Ile leaue you though I feare.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Goe, thou art honeſt,
Why ſhould the haſtie errors of my youth
Be ſo vnpardonable, to draw a ſinne
Helpeleſſe vpon me?

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.p: There is the King, now it is ripe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Draw neere thou guiltie man,
That art the author of the loathedſt crime
Fiue ages haue brought forth, and heare me ſpeake
Curſes incurable, and all the euils
Mans b • die or his ſpirit can receiue
Be with thee.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: VVhy Sir doe you curſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: VVhy doe I curſe thee, if there be a man
Subtill in curſes, that exceedes the reſt,
His worſt wiſh on thee. Thou haſt broke my hart.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: How Sir? Haue I preſeru'd you from a childe,
From all the arrowes, malice or ambition
Could ſhoot at you, and haue I this for pay?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Tis true thou didſt preſerue me, and in that
VVert crueiler then hardned murderers
Of Infants and their mothers; thou didſt ſaue me
Onely till thou hadſt ſtuddied out a way
How to deſtroy me cunningly thy ſelfe:
This was a curious way of torturing.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Thou knowſt the euils thou haſt done to me,
Doſt thou remember all thoſe witching letters
Thou ſentſt vnto me to Armenia,
Fild with the praiſe of my beloued Siſter,
Where thou extolſt her beautie; what had I
To doe with that, what could her beautie be
To me, and thou didſt write how well ſhee lou'd me,
Doeſt thou remember this: ſo that I doated
Something before I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This is true.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Is it, and • when I was returnd thou knowſt
Thou didſt purſue it, till thou woundſt mee into
Such a ſtrange, and vnbeleeu'd affection,
As good men cannot thinke on.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This I grant, I thinke I was the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: VVert thou▪ Nay more, I thinke thou meantſt it.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Sir I haue a lie
As I loue God and honeſtie, I did:
It was my meaning.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Be thine owne ſad Iudge,
A further condemnation will not need:
Prepare thy ſelfe to die.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: VVhy Sir to die?
VVhy wouldſt thou liue, was euer yet offendor
So impudent, that had a thought of mercy
After confeſſion of a crime like this?
Get out I cannot, where thou hurlſt me in,
But I can take reuenge, that's all the ſweetneſſe
Left for me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Now is the time, heare me but ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, yet I will be farre more mercifull
Then thou wert to me; thou didſt ſteale into me,
And neuer gaueſt me warning: ſo much time
As I giue thee now, had preuented thee
For euer. Notwithſtanding all thy ſinnes,
If thou haſt hope, that there is yet a prayer
To ſaue thee, turne, and ſpeake it to your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall know your ſinnes before you doe vm If you kill me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will not ſtay then.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Know you kill your Father.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You kill your Father.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: My Father? though I know it for a lie
Made out of feare to ſaue thy ſtained life:
The verie reuerence of the word comes croſſe me,
And ties mine arme downe.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: I will tell you that ſhall heighten you againe, I am thy
Father, I charge thee heare me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: If it ſhould be ſo,
As tis moſt falſe, and that I ſhould be ſound
A baſtard iſſue, the diſpiſed fruite
Of lawleſſe luſt, I ſhould no more admire
All my wilde paſſions: but another truth
Shall be wrung from thee: If I could come by
The ſpirit of paine, it ſhould be powr'd on thee,
Till thou alloweſt thy ſelfe more full of lies
Then he that teaches thee.

sp.speaker: Arane.
sp.l: Turne thee about,
I come to ſpeake to thee thou wicked man,
Heare me thou Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will turne to thee,
Heare me thou Strumpet: I haue blotted out
The name of mother, as thou haſt thy ſhame.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: My ſhame, thou haſt leſſe ſhame then any thing:
Why doſt thou keepe my daughter in a priſon?
Why doſt thou call her Siſter, and doe this?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Ceaſe thou ſtrange impudence, and anſwere quickly,
If thou contemn'ſt me, this will aske an anſwere,
And haue it.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Helpe me gentle Gobrius.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Guilt dare not helpe guilt, though they grow together
In doing ill, yet at the puniſhment
They ſeuer, and each flies the noyſe of other,
Thinke not of helpe, anſwere.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I will, to what?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: To ſuch a thing as if it be a truth,
Thinke what a creature thou haſt made thy ſelfe,
That didſt not ſhame to doe, what I muſt bluſh
Onely to aske thee: tell me who I am,
Whoſe ſonne I am, without all circumſtance;
Be thou as haſtie, as my Sword will be
If thou refuſeſt.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: VVhy you are his ſonne.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: His ſonne?
Sweare, ſweare, thou worſe then woman damn'd.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: By all thats good you are.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Then art thou all that euer was knowne bad. Now is
The cauſe of all my ſtrange miſfortunes come to light:
What reuerence expects thou from a childe
To bring forth which thou haſt offended Heauen,
Thy husband and the Land: Adulterous witch
I know now why thou wouldſt haue poyſon'd me,
I was thy luſt which thou wouldſt haue forgot:
Thou wicked mother of my ſinnes, and me,
Shew me the way to the inheritance
I haue by thee: which is a ſpacious world
Of impious acts, that I may ſoone poſſeſſe it:
Plagues rott thee, as thou liu'ſt, and ſuch diſeaſes
As vſe to pay luſt, recompence thy deed.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You doe not know why you curſe thus.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Too well:
You are a paire of Vipers, and behold
The Serpent you haue got; there is no beaſt
But if he knew, it has a pedigree
As braue as mine, for they haue more diſcents,
And I am euery way as beaſtly got,
As farre without the compaſſe of a law,
As they.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: You ſpend your rage, and words in vaine,
And raile vpon a gueſſe: heare vs a little.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No I will neuer heare, but talke away
My breath, and die.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: VVhy but you are no Baftard.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Howe's that?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Nor childe of mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Still you goe on in wonders to me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Pray be more patient, I may bring comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I will kneele,
And heare with the obedience of a childe;
Good Father ſpeake, I doe acknowledge you,
So you bring comfort.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Firſt know our laſt King your ſuppoſed Father
VVas olde and feeble when he marryed her,
And almoſt all the Land as ſhee paſt hope
Of iſſue from him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Therefore ſhee tooke leaue
To play the whoore, becauſe the King was old:
Is this the comfort?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: vvhat will you find out
To giue me ſatiſfaction, when you find
How you haue iniur'd me: let fire conſume mee,
If euer I were whore.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Forbeare theſe ſtarts,
Or I will leaue you wedded to deſpaire,
As you are now: if you can find a temper,
My breath ſhall be a pleaſant weſterne wind,
That cooles, and blaſtes not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Bring it out good Father,
Ile lie, and liſten here as reuerentlie
As to an Angell: If I breathe too loude,
Tell me; for I would be as ſtill as night.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Our King I ſay was old, and this our Queene
Deſired to bring an heire; but yet her husband
Shee thought was paſt it, and to be diſhoneſt
I thinke ſhee would not; if ſhee would haue beene,
The truth is, ſhee was watcht ſo narrowlie,
And had ſo ſlender opportunitie,
Shee hardly could haue beene: But yet her cunning
Found out this way; ſhee fain'd her ſelfe with child,
And poſtes were ſent in haſte throughout the Land,
And God was humbly thankt in euery Church,
That ſo had bleſt the Queen, and prayers were made
For her ſafe going, and deliuerie:
Shee fain'd now to grow bigger, and perceiu'd
This hope of iſſue made her feard, and brought
A farre more large reſpect from euerie man,
And ſaw her power increaſe, and was reſolu'd,
Since ſhee belieu'd ſhee could not haue't indeede;
At leaſt ſhee would be thought to haue a child.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Doe I not heare it well; nay, I will make
No noiſe at all; but pray you to the point,
Quicke as you can.

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.l: Now when the time was full,
Shee ſhould be brought abed; I had a ſonne
Borne, which was you: This the Queene hearing of,
Mou'd me to let her haue you, and ſuch reaſons
Shee ſhewed me as ſhee knew would tie
My ſecreſie: ſhee ſware you ſhould be King;
And o be ſhort, • did deliue • you
Vnto her, and pretended you we e dead;
And in mine owne houſe kept a Funerall,
And had an emprie coffin put in earth:
That night the Queene fain'd haſtilie to labour,
And by a paire of women of her owne.
VVhich ſhee had charm'd, ſhee made the world belieue
Shee was deliuer'd of you: you grew vp
As the Kings ſonne▪ till you were ſixe yeere olde;
Then did the King die, and did leaue to me
Protection of the Realme; and contrarie
To his owne expectation, left this Queene
Truly with childe indeed of the faire Princeſſe
Panthaea: Then ſhee could haue torne her heire,
And did alone to me yet durſt not ſpeake
In publi • e; for ſhee knew ſhee ſhould be found
A Traytor, and her talke would haue beene thought
Madneſſe or any thing rather then truth:
This was the onely cauſe why ſhee did ſeeke
To poyſon you, and I to keepe you ſafe:
And this the reaſon why I ſought to kindle
Some ſparke of loue in you to faire Panthaea,
That ſhee might get part of her right agen.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And haue you made an end now, is this all?
If not, I will be ſtill till I am aged,
Till all my heires are ſiluer.

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And is it true ſay you Maddam?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yes God knowes it is moſt true.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Panthaea then is not my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Gob
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But can you proue this?
If you will giue conſent: elſe who dare goe about it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Giue conſent?
VVhy I will haue them all that know it rackt
To get this from vm: All that waites without
Come in, what ere you be come in, and be
Partakers of my Ioy: O you are welcome.
Mardonius the beſt newes, nay, draw no neerer
They all ſhall heare it: I am found no King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is that ſo good newes?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Yes, the happieſt newes that ere was heard.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed twere well for you,
If you might be a little leſſe obey'd.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: On, call the Queene.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why ſhe is there.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The Queene Mardonius, Panthaea is the Queene,
And I am plaine Arbaces, goe ſome one,
She is in Gobrius houſe; ſince I ſaw you
There are a thouſand things deliuerd to me
You little dreame of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So it ſhould ſeeme: My Lord,
VVhat furi's this.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.l: Beleeue me tis no fury,
All that he ſayes is truth.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: Tis verie ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: Why doe you keepe your hats off Gentlemen,
Is it to me? 〈◊〉 good faith it muſt not be:
I cannot now command you, but I pray you
For the reſpect you bare me, when you tooke
Me for your King, each man clap on his hat at my deſire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We will: but you are not found
So meane a man, but that you may be couer'd
As well as we, may you not?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O not here,
You may but not I, for here is my Father in preſence,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: VVhere?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Why there O the whole ſtorie
Would be a wilderneſſe to looſe thy ſelfe
For euer; O pardon me deare Father,
For all the idle, and vnreuerent words
That I haue ſpoke in idle moodes to you:
I am Arbaces, we all fellow ſubiects,
Nor is the Queene Panthaa now my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Why if you remember fellow ſubiect Arbaces, I tolde you once ſhe was not your ſiſter, I ſay ſhe look't nothing like you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I thinke you did good Captaine Beſſus.

sp.speaker: Beſ.
sp.p: Here will ariſe another queſtion now amongſt the Swordmen, whether I be to call him to account for beating me, now he's prou'd no King.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir, heres Ligones
The Agent for the Armenian King.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Where is he, I know your buſineſſe good Ligones,

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: VVe muſt haue our King againe, and will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I knew that was your buſineſſe, you ſhall haue
Your King againe, and haue him ſo againe
As neuer King was had. Goe one of you
And bid Bacurius bring Tigranes hither,
And bring the Ladie with him, that Panthaea
The Queene Panthaa ſent me word this morning
VVas braue Tigranes miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: Tis Spaconia.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I, I, Spaconia.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.p: She is my daughter.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Shee is ſo, I could now tell any thing
I neuer heard; your King ſhall goe ſo home
As neuer man went.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Shall he goe on's head?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: He ſhall haue Chariots eaſier then ayre
That I will haue inuented; and nere thinke
He ſhall pay any ranſome; and thy ſelfe
That art the Meſſenger ſhall ride before him
On a Horſe cut out of an entire Diamond,
That ſhall be made to goe with golden wheeles,
I know not how yet.

sp.speaker: Lig.
sp.l: VVhy I ſhall be made
For euer, they belied this King with vs
And ſavd he was vnkind.

sp.speaker: Arb
sp.l: And then thy daughter,
She ſhall haue ſome ſtrange thinke, wele haue the kingdome
Sold vtterly, and put into a toy.
Which ſhe ſhall weare about her careleſly
Some where or other.
See the vertuous Queene.
Behold the humbleſt ſubiect that you haue
Kneele here before you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: VVhy kneele you
To me that am your vaſſall?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Grant me one requeſt.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Alas, what can I grant you?
VVhat I can I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: That you will pleaſe to marry me,
If I can proue it lawfull.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is that all?
More willingly, then I would draw this ayre.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Ile kiſſe this hand in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, Tigranes is comming though he made it ſtrange
To ſee the Princeſſe any more.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The Queene,
Thou meaneſt: O my Tigranes pardon me,
Tread on my necke I freely offer it,
And if thou beeſt ſo giuen; take reuenge,
For I haue iniur'd thee.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.l: No, I forgiue,
And rejoice more that you haue found repentance,
Then I my libertie.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Maiſt thou be happie
In thy faire choice; for thou art temperate:
You owe no ranſome to the ſtate, know that;
I haue a thouſand ioyes to tell you of,
vvhich yet I dare not v • ter, till I pay
My thankes to Heauen for vm: will you goe
vvith me, and •• l e me; pray you doe.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Take then your faire one with you, and your Queene
Of goodneſſe, and of vs; O giue me leaue
To take your arme in mine: Come euery one
That takes delight in goodneſſe, helpe to ſing
Loude thankes for me, that I am prou'd no King.
